docs.lead_paragraph: Health Care for America Now, a coalition of Democratic and labor groups, began running $650,000 worth of television commercials on Monday against various Republicans who have opposed overhauling the health care system. The advertisements question whether these members of Congress are opposed to changing health care because they are in the pocket of the insurance companies and already have good coverage for themselves.
docs.abstract: Democratic and labor coalition Health Care for America Now begins running $650,000 worth of television commercials against various Republicans who oppose overhauling health care system; ads suggest opponents are in insurance companies' pockets and already have good care themselves; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Health Care for America Now, a coalition of Democratic and labor groups, began running $650,000 worth of television commercials on Monday against various Republicans who have opposed overhauling the health care system.     The advertisements question...

docs.lead_paragraph: Retreating from a government-run insurance plan may help the Obama administration gain bipartisan support for a health care overhaul. But can it bridge the generation gap? Older Americans were not really on board with overhauling the system in the first place and have been the age group most resistant to change, according to various surveys. Among them was a Gallup poll in July that indicated fewer than half of Medicare-age people favored changing the system, fearing their own medical care would worsen. Similarly, a CNN/Opinion Research Corporation survey showed the contrast with younger voters, who strongly favor a change.
docs.abstract: Various surveys show older Americans have never really favored overhauling health care system, fearing that that their own medical care would worsen; overwhelming majority of older people already have health insurance; Obama administration's apparent retreat from government-run insurance plan may not be enough to win more support from older people; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Retreating from a government-run insurance plan may help the Obama administration gain bipartisan support for a health care overhaul. But can it bridge the generation gap?      Older Americans were not really on board with overhauling the system in...

docs.lead_paragraph: Even though Congress is adjourned, the Gang of Six is eager to talk. The gang -- the six members of the Senate Finance Committee who are actually writing what may be the pivotal piece of health care legislation -- is planning its first formal discussion since the Senate recessed Aug 7.
docs.abstract: Senate Finance Committee is planning teleconference for its first formal discussion of health care legislation since Senate recessed and Pres Obama signaled that he might drop idea of government-run insurance plan; notes that committee's six senators never really liked so-called public option (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Q. How do most Americans obtain health insurance? A. According to census estimates, nearly 85 percent of the population had some form of coverage in 2007, and more than two-thirds of those people received it through an employer. Public programs like Medicare and Medicaid cover older people, the disabled and veterans, along with many children and low-income people.
docs.abstract: Nearly 85 percent of Americans had some form of health insurance coverage in 2007; more than two-thirds of them received it through their employer; public programs, like Medicare and Medicaid, cover older people, disabled and veterans, along with many children and low-income people (S)
